title: 108_hr3297
content: The Counterfeit Drug Enforcement Act is cited as the short title. It amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to include a new section on recall authority for drugs. The Counterfeit Drug Enforcement Act introduces a new section on recall authority for drugs. If the Secretary determines a drug poses serious health risks, an order is issued to cease distribution and notify health professionals promptly. An informal hearing must be provided within 10 days. The Counterfeit Drug Enforcement Act introduces a new section on recall authority for drugs. An informal hearing must be held within 10 days to discuss the actions required by the order and the possibility of amending it to include a drug recall. If inadequate grounds exist, the Secretary will vacate the order. If necessary, the Secretary will amend the order to require a drug recall with a specified timetable. The Counterfeit Drug Enforcement Act introduces a new section on recall authority for drugs. An amended order may include a drug recall with a specified timetable and require periodic reports to the Secretary on the progress of the recall. The order shall not recall drugs from individuals but provide notice to individuals at risk. The Secretary may seek assistance from health professionals in notifying individuals about the risks associated with the drug. SEC. 3. Sale or trade of prescription drugs knowingly caused to be adulterated or misbranded; knowing purchase or trade. Criminal penalties for violating drug regulations include fines, imprisonment, or both. Manufacturers must notify the FDA about certain drugs. The FDA requires drug manufacturers to report any information suggesting a violation within 48 hours. Additionally, $60 million is authorized for FDA inspections and investigations related to drug violations from 2004 to 2008. SEC. 4. OTHER CRIMINAL PENALTIES; CLARIFICATION REGARDING FINES. Section 303 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to impose fines or imprisonment for violations, with varying penalties based on the severity of the offense. The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to impose fines or imprisonment for violations, with penalties up to 10 years in prison or fines according to title 18, United States Code.
